entry.title: Re: Enable Now ‚Äì Table of contents and audio integration...
entry.content:
Hi team Wibke,

It is not possible to create links to internal sections of a scrollable page.  Unfortunately, the HTML cleaner in Enable Now modifies the links, including internal links, and the modified version of the link does not work if the link is to another section of the same page.

It would be possible to play different audio as the user scrolls down the page, however, you will have to consider the best way to trigger that audio.  Using Enable Now, you can add multiple audio files to a single page and then trigger the relevant audio for the corresponding section.

 

 

 

The easiest way that I can think to trigger the audio is to get users to play it when they are ready.  You could easily do that by adding buttons to the page, at the relevant points, and setting up an action to play the relevant piece of audio when the user clicks the corresponding button.

 

 

 

Hope that helps.

Regards
Shane

entry.title: Introduction to API in SAP ABAP
entry.content:
Introduction to REST APIs in SAP ABAP ‚Äì A Beginner-Friendly Guide

In today‚Äôs digital landscape, integration is at the heart of every business process. Whether it‚Äôs connecting SAP with e-commerce platforms, CRMs, payment gateways, or cloud applications‚ÄîAPIs play a crucial role in making systems communicate smoothly and securely.

As SAP evolves, an ABAP developer is no longer limited to classical reports and enhancements.

We now work in a world where REST APIs, JSON payloads, and HTTP calls are becoming everyday essentials.

This blog marks Part 1 of my API Series for SAP Developers, where I break down core API concepts in simple words, along with how they relate to SAP ABAP.

What is an API? 

  • API stands for Application Programming Interface‚Äîa structured way for two systems to communicate.

Think of an API as a messenger that carries a request from one system and brings back a response from another.

For example:

  • SAP retrieving live weather details from a weather API
  • SAP sending order data to a third-party logistics system
  • SAP fetching exchange rates from an external service

Understanding REST and RESTful APIs

  • REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style that defines how systems interact using simple, lightweight standards‚Äîusually over HTTP.

A REST API follows these REST principles and works on the basis of:

‚û°Ô∏è A Request sent by the client

‚û°Ô∏è A Response returned by the server

This makes REST APIs fast, scalable, and widely used.

Structure of an API Request

A typical API request consists of four key elements:

1. Endpoint

  • The URL where the request is sent.

Example: /weather/data/city=Berlin

2. Method (HTTP Verb)

  • Defines the action to perform.

Method Purpose:

  1. GET Retrieve data
  2. POST Create new data
  3. PUT Replace/update full data
  4. PATCH Update partial data
  5. DELETE Remove data

3. Headers

  • Used for authentication (API key, bearer token) and metadata (content type, encoding).

4. Body (Payload)

  • The actual data being sent‚Äîusually JSON or XML.

Example (JSON):

{

  "city": "Berlin",

  "unit": "celsius"

}

Prerequisites in SAP to Consume an API:

  • Before calling an API from SAP ABAP, ensure:
  • ‚úî SICF Service is Active
  • SAP uses ICF (Internet Communication Framework) for HTTP/HTTPS calls.
  • Transaction: SICF
  • ‚úî Required Authorizations
  • Your user should have permissions for:
  • Making HTTP calls
  • Accessing destinations
  • Using classes like CL_HTTP_CLIENT

How SAP ABAP Communicates with APIs:

API provides robust classes to make HTTP calls:

  • CL_HTTP_CLIENT ‚Äì Create and send requests
  • IF_HTTP_CLIENT ‚Äì Handle and process responses

With these, you can:

‚úî Send GET/POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE calls

‚úî Send JSON/XML body

‚úî Read and parse JSON responses

‚úî Connect SAP to external cloud services

This opens doors to integrations like:

  •  Fetching weather data
  • Connecting to payment gateways
  • Sending delivery data to logistics providers
  • Communicating with AI/ML APIs

Example Use Cases for APIs in ABAP

Here are some real-world scenarios where ABAP developers use APIs:

1. Integrating SAP with a CRM

  • Send customer details to Salesforce or HubSpot using POST calls.

2. Fetching Live Data

  • Retrieve stock prices, exchange rates, or weather details in real time.

3. Automating External Processes

  • Send purchase order confirmations to vendor portals.

4. Connecting SAP to Cloud Applications

  • Use REST APIs to integrate SAP with cloud apps, chatbots, mobile apps, and dashboards.

Conclusion

  • In modern SAP landscapes, REST APIs are not just a concept‚Äîthey are a necessity.

As an ABAP developer, understanding APIs empowers you to:

  • Build smarter integrations
  • Automate cross-platform workflows
  • Connect SAP with the outside world
  • Stay aligned with SAP‚Äôs shift toward cloud and digital transformation
  • This blog sets the foundation.

Stay tuned for Part 2 of the API series!

Your feedback and suggestions are always welcome. üòä

entry.title: Performance Optimization Strategies for Marketplace App Scenarios in SAP Commerce Cloud
entry.content:
I‚Äôm looking to gather insights and best practices on improving performance for marketplace-based applications built on SAP Commerce Cloud. Marketplace setups often introduce additional complexity‚Äîmultiple sellers, high product volumes, heavy API usage, and dynamic pricing or inventory updates‚Äîwhich can significantly impact site speed and scalability.
In addition to SAP Commerce Cloud‚Äôs built-in tuning options, I‚Äôm also interested in how teams are leveraging Cloudflare to enhance overall performance, security, and stability.
Specifically, I‚Äôd like to hear about:

  • Proven performance optimization techniques for large-scale marketplace apps in SAP Commerce Cloud
  • Managing high traffic, seller onboarding, and large catalog structures efficiently
  • Cache strategies (platform-level, CDN-level, and Cloudflare-specific optimizations like caching rules, Workers, and edge functions)
  • How Cloudflare has helped reduce load, improve response times, or mitigate spikes in traffic
  • Handling API-heavy marketplace interactions with minimal latency
  • Any performance pitfalls you‚Äôve encountered and how you addressed them


If you‚Äôve tuned a marketplace system, integrated Cloudflare, or built performance monitoring pipelines, your experiences would be incredibly valuable.

entry.title: Query about non factory static action in RAP
entry.content:
I have a doubt regarding non factory static action defined in RAP (for this example, lets consider in RAP Managed).

So there is a list report, where an action button "IncreasePrice" is visible (even when none of the record is selected) as the action is defined as static. Till here , its fine.

Now when I go to implement the method for this action in behaviour implementation, I see there is importing parameter "keys" which contains only %cid. So I have the below questions now.

1) Since I have defined non factory static instance, which means its not for CREATION of instances and not applicable to a particular instance , then what is the use of this importing parameter "keys" which contains %cid ?

2) I observed that when i select , lets say 3 records from the list report and click on this action, the corresponding method gets triggered thrice, which is surprising for me because this is supposed to be a static action to be triggered on the entity level and not on instance level. Imagine if I am writing some logic to be applied at entity level, it will be called 3 times because of this , which is not expected from static action I think.

3) In the implementation method for this action, if I have to apply some change in value for all instances of this entity (something which is expected from a static action) , I guess I would need to loop through all the instances and use MODIFY Entities to do that.

  But to loop through the instances, I will need to maybe first READ all the instances in an itab using READ ENTITIES , however in READ ENTITIES we are supposed to give some where condition for keys and in this static action, I do not have anything apart from %cid in the importing parameter , so how do i READ all the records. (Or maybe there is some other way to do which I am unaware).

Thanks a lot in advance.

entry.title: Re: How to use „ÄåScrap in %„Äçin Routing master
entry.content:
Good day @SONG_PANLONG 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references

Operation Scrap, Scrap Component Group Materials

Planned Cost (Preliminary Costing of Manufacturing Orders), Production Orders in Cost Object Controlling

In summary, the Scrap in % is used in public cloud when your operation is expected to produce some losses during processing (e.g., cutting operations). That means your planned quantity, component quantities and production cost calculation will be affected because it takes the Scrap in % into consideration. Scrap is tied to an operation and not the entire Bill of Materials for your final product. It is appropriate when only a specific routing step is responsible for the generation of waste.

On your question about how production order and production costs are affected, Scrap in % simply increases your input quantity, consumes more component and thereby increasing your cost of production. You can only see its impact after you have exploded the routing into your production order.

Below is a step-by-step guidance on how to view the Scrap in %

In your Manage Routings, search for a desired product

Open the Routing and find the General Data field. Here you will see the Scrap (%)

Under Components, you chan check if the system adjusted quantities if Scrap % was applied.

Finally go to the Create Production Order app, enter your details. Then check your component overview, your operations quantities and costing tab. There you will see increased consumption and recalculated costs.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Actual Cost Accounting and Moving Average Cost
entry.content:
Good morning sir , 

>Does SAP's actual cost accounting only calculate items with standard cost settings?

YES . 

>How are items with moving average cost settings calculated when they are mixed with other items?

Every time when the stock quantity or amount increased , unit price will be recalculated :
unit price = total amount / total quantity  

then when you do the goods issue , the cost will be based on the new unit price like :
COGS = goods issue quantity * unit price. 

 

please have a look at this blog for more details :
What Is the Difference Between Moving Average Price and Standard Price in SAP?

 

best regards 

Shi Zhekui

entry.title: Building a Production-Ready SAP Composable Storefront: Architecture, Best Practices & Blueprint
entry.content:
Introduction

As commerce landscapes evolve toward composability, frontend architectures must deliver speed, modularity, resilience, and seamless integration with enterprise ecosystems.
SAP Composable Storefront, built on Angular and powered by OCC APIs, offers a modern, headless, and flexible foundation for B2B/B2C experiences ‚Äî but building it for production requires deliberate architectural choices and strong engineering discipline.

In this blog, I provide a practical and deeply technical blueprint for designing, implementing, and running a production-ready SAP Composable Storefront application. Whether you're an architect, senior engineer, or SAP Commerce integrator, these guidelines will help you scale efficiently, avoid common pitfalls, and achieve high performance on the edge.

1. Architectural Overview

SAP Composable Storefront is essentially an Angular application composed from Spartacus libraries with custom modules layered on top. It communicates with SAP Commerce Cloud via:

  • OCC REST APIs (product, cart, checkout, CMS)

  • Third-party services (identity, search, payments, analytics)

  • Edge/CDN layers (for caching & performance)

High-Level Flow

  1. User request hits the CDN. If an SSR HTML page is cached ‚Üí return instantly.

  2. If not cached, request is forwarded to the SSR Node server pool.

  3. Once delivered, the Angular client hydrates and fetches additional data from Commerce APIs.

  4. Connectors, adapters, and interceptors handle mapping, authentication, and context (site/catalog/currency).

Design Goals

  • Modular, maintainable features

  • Clean separation of concerns

  • Efficient API mapping & error handling

  • Strong observability and operational readiness

  • High performance on edge delivery

2. Project Setup & Recommended Foundation

A solid foundation begins with the right scaffolding. The recommended project initialization:

ng new my-storefront --routing --style=scss
cd my-storefront
ng add /schematics --ssr

After running Spartacus schematics:

  • Configure environment.ts with occBaseUrl, site, and API prefix

  • Validate Commerce Cloud compatibility matrix

  • Choose feature libraries (B2B, Wishlists, CDS, CDC, etc.)

  • Establish a multi-env config strategy: dev / staging / prod / SSR / preview

3. Folder Structure & Module Strategy

A clean folder structure is critical for scalability in large storefront implementations.

src/
  app/
    core/         ‚Üí interceptors, guards, root services
    shared/       ‚Üí UI components, directives, pipes
    features/     ‚Üí cart, product, checkout, account, etc.
    config/       ‚Üí all Spartacus + application configs
    styles/       ‚Üí SCSS tokens, global mixins, theming
  server/         ‚Üí Angular Universal SSR code
  assets/         ‚Üí images, i18n, icons

Core Principles

  • CoreModule contains all singletons.

  • SharedModule contains pure components, no business logic.

  • Feature Modules are route-based and lazily loaded.

  • Config Modules centralize Spartacus and custom configurations.

This organization prevents module bloat and ensures low coupling.

4. Theming, Styling & Asset Strategy

  • Use SCSS with centralized variables/tokens (_tokens.scss)

  • Prefer BEM methodology for predictable styling

  • Keep global styles minimal

  • Host large asset bundles on a CDN in production

  • Use WebP and responsive image sets for performance

  • Avoid overriding Spartacus styles excessively ‚Äî extend, don‚Äôt fork

5. Data Flow: Connectors, Adapters & Mappers

SAP Composable Storefront‚Äôs architecture encourages clean data handling:

Best Practices

  • Keep raw OCC models in adapters

  • Map OCC ‚Üí UI-friendly models in dedicated mappers

  • Use HTTP interceptors for:

    • Auth token injection

    • Site/tenant context headers

    • Request correlation IDs

  • Keep services thin; let adapters handle network concerns

  • Implement custom endpoints using Spartacus‚Äô OccConfig extension approach

This ensures maintainability through upgrades and avoids code duplication.

6. State Management & RxJS Best Practices

Spartacus already ships with internal NgRx stores; custom state can extend it cleanly.

Guidelines

  • Prefer async pipes instead of manual subscription/unsubscription

  • Use OnPush change detection for all components

  • Apply correct RxJS operators:

    • switchMap ‚Üí dependent API calls

    • exhaustMap ‚Üí checkout flow steps

    • combineLatest ‚Üí merged UI streams

  • Keep state local wherever possible ‚Äî global store only when necessary

7. Server-Side Rendering (SSR) & Pre-Rendering

SSR is essential for SEO and for first-load performance of SAP storefronts.

Key SSR Considerations

  • Leverage Angular Universal for rendering

  • Pre-render static routes (homepage, category pages)

  • Implement fast fallback for SSR server failures

  • Always guard DOM access using:

if (isPlatformBrowser(this.platformId)) {
  // browser-only logic
}

Scaling SSR

  • Deploy SSR nodes behind a load balancer

  • Use horizontal autoscaling based on CPU/memory

  • Cache SSR HTML aggressively at the CDN

8. Performance, Caching & CDN Strategy

Recommendations

  • Use long cache TTLs with content-hashed asset filenames

  • Enable API-level caching for read-only endpoints (CMS, product, categories)

  • Implement lazy loading & route-based code splitting

  • Consider image optimization and responsive formats

  • Cache SSR output at CDN for key pages

  • Monitor TTFB and Core Web Vitals continuously

This significantly reduces backend loads and improves Lighthouse scores.

9. Security Considerations

  • Enforce HTTPS everywhere

  • Apply Content Security Policy (CSP) headers

  • Use HttpOnly cookies for tokens when possible

  • Sanitize CMS-driven HTML

  • Rate-limit OCC endpoints at the gateway layer

  • Avoid leaking internal config via environment files

Security must be treated as a continuous practice, not a one-time setup.

10. Testing Strategy

Layers of Testing

  • Unit tests ‚Üí Services, components, mappers

  • Integration tests ‚Üí Using Cypress or Playwright

  • Visual regression tests ‚Üí Percy or Playwright snapshots

  • Contract tests ‚Üí Pact against OCC

  • API mocks for local development

A mature storefront requires confidence across all layers.

11. CI/CD & Deployment Patterns

A modern pipeline should include:

  1. Linting

  2. Unit tests

  3. Build (client + server bundles)

  4. Integration/E2E tests

  5. Deploy to staging

  6. Canary/Blue-Green deployment

  7. Final production release

Infrastructure Guidance

  • SSR Nodes deployed in Kubernetes

  • Zero-downtime rolling updates

  • Automatic CDN cache invalidation on release

  • Tight integration with observability stack

12. Monitoring & Operational Runbook

Monitoring Stack

  • Error tracking (Sentry / Dynatrace / Kibana)

  • Node SSR logs with correlation IDs

  • Alerts for:

    • Memory pressure

    • 5xx spikes

    • Slow OCC endpoints

    • CDN cache miss patterns

Runbook Should Include

  • How to disable SSR in emergencies

  • Cache purge strategy

  • Rollback instructions

  • Recovering from Commerce outages

This ensures stable operations even under stress.

13. Extensibility, Upgrades & Governance

To keep the storefront healthy long-term:

  • Never fork Spartacus libraries

  • Maintain compatibility matrix with Commerce & Spartacus versions

  • Use linting + Angular style guide

  • Treat every new feature as an isolated module

  • Have a structured upgrade plan for both Angular & Spartacus versions

Good governance reduces technical debt dramatically.

Conclusion

Building a production-ready SAP Composable Storefront requires more than installing Spartacus libraries ‚Äî it demands a carefully crafted architecture, operational excellence, and adherence to enterprise-grade engineering standards.

By following the patterns outlined above, teams can deliver storefronts that are:

  • Performant

  • Composable

  • Upgrade-friendly

  • Highly maintainable

  • Secure

  • Ready for enterprise scale

This blueprint aligns with SAP‚Äôs recommended best practices and equips teams to deliver future-proof digital commerce experiences.

entry.title: Re: #CoE#GB How to schedule a report in SAP S/4HANA Cloud...
entry.content:
Good day @Nelson_Yu1 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references

Custom Analytical Queries, Schedule Jobs, Schedule Export of Inventory Analytics, Output Parameter Determination, Key User Extensibility, Query Browser

Blog: BRF+ Output Determination

In summary, the public cloud does not allow you to schedule custom analytical queries and query browser reports with conditions. It also does not permit sending results automatically through email due to its clean-core principle.

The clean-core approach offers a workaround where you can use the Schedule Accounts Receivable/Payable Apps to create a schedule, generate email and you can filter some parameters (e.g., Schedule General Ledger Jobs, Schedule Inventory Jobs, etc.) for some released analytical job templates only, if your business requirements fit these domains.

Optionally, you can also consider using the Export to Excel and Email function (e.g., to extract schedule, deliver email attachment, etc.,) through Output Management by creating the Custom Analytical Query, Create Custom CDS View and use it in an OData API. Then you can consume the OData API through SAP Build Process Automation or External scheduler.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Notification for SAP Cloud ALM Feature Approval
entry.content:
In this scenario, tagging will not help with the notification aspect. It will simply give the approvers another field that they can use in their searches (via the Features app). The workflow would be that the approver would access the Features app, and add the specific tag for approval as a filter criteria. Then they will see what Features require their approval. When they take the necessary action, they would remove the tag, thus removing the Feature from their search results. There would be no notification in this process.

Our Developers recently published a new blog post discussing enabling External Workflows for Features in SAP Cloud ALM. It illustrates how to establish test approvals and confirmations for Features via external workflows. These external workflows can be configured to send e-mail notifications in response to those events. You may be able to adapt this concept to getting the kind of notifications that you desire.

entry.title: Re: Issue with reversal of a GR for Sub-Contract PO from...
entry.content:
Hi @sumukhip ,
The issue you are encountering is a known issue in decentralized EWM‚ÄìECC integration. When reversing a Goods Receipt for a Subcontracting PO, ECC expects inbound delivery line items for all consumed components. If those items are missing or mismatched, the reversal fails with the ‚Äúenter item‚Äù error in SMQ2. The resolution typically involves ensuring inbound delivery item consistency, adjusting customizing for GR reversal, or applying SAP notes/patches that enhance VL09 handling for EWM-driven reversals.

You can try few options to resolve this as mentioned below.

1. Inbound Delivery Item Check: Ensure inbound delivery has all component items linked to the PO. If items are missing, manually adjust the inbound delivery before retrying reversal.

2. GR Reversal Settings in EWM: SAP introduced enhancements like ‚ÄúReverse after Putaway‚Äù and Enhanced GRR functionality in newer releases (S/4HANA 2021 FPS01 onward). These allow partial reversals and better handling of inbound deliveries. In older ECC/EWM setups, reversal is often ‚Äúall-or-nothing‚Äù at the Goods Movement document level.

3. SAP Notes / OSS Messages: Several customers reported similar failures in SAP Community. The workaround was either applying corrective SAP notes or upgrading to a release where GRR supports single inbound delivery reversals.

Example: SAP note fixes ensure VL09 doesn‚Äôt require all components if reversal is for a single batch.

4. Manual Workaround: Reverse the GR in ECC directly using VL09 with the inbound delivery reference, ensuring all items are selected. Then reprocess the failed queue in SMQ2.

Hope above options will resolve your issue

entry.title: Re: Deployment Scheduling in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Hi @moritzgysler,

Thanks for the blog, it's been of great help and the deployment scheduler definitely helps us in automated scheduled deployments.

There is one thing we have noticed, recently due to the end of the Daylight savings time in Europe we noticed that our scheduled deployments were 1 hour earlier in the S4 system compared to the time set in ALM scheduler. We raised an incident (1335407/2025 ) for this and it was mentioned ALM scheduler doesn't support winter & summer times and the workaround was to keep changing the times manually in ALM scheduler. While disappointing to hear we changed the time manually but now the time scheduled in ALM matches the deployment time in S4 system. So a bit confusing.

It would be good to have the timezone functionality in the ALM scheduler to avoid this confusion.

Regards,

Sheldon

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to use Account Assignment Category ‚ÄòQ‚Äô...
entry.content:
Dear @Vinod_K,

In Public Cloud you can use Account Assignment Category Q only with WBS elements that belong to Investment Projects or Projects with Revenue and have project stock enabled. For normal Customer Projects where the WBS is not of these types (no project stock), Q is not supported, so your error CN769 is expected system behavior.

SAP Note describes exactly your situation in Public Cloud:

  • You create a PO in Manage Purchase Orders
  • Set Account Assignment Category = Q
  • Enter a WBS that does not belong to Investment Project or Project with Revenue
  • System raises CN769 WBS element has different inventory valuation

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3204437

Best Regards,

Dawid

Hello @JAS3311 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references

Manage Supplier Invoices, Display Supplier Invoice - Advanced, Attachment Service, Posting Supplier Invoices.

Also check out this Blog: SAP Fiori Attachment Service - An implementation guide for your SAPUI5 project

In summary, due to the public cloud clean-core principle, it is not possible to add a clickable URL directly to a posted supplier invoice. Once you post an invoice, the system locks the document to ensure you comply with legal and audit restrictions. The system allows you to upload files (e.g., PDFs, images etc.) because of the attachment framework design but does not allow links to be stored or opened.

If you need to reference an external document while adhering to the clean-core principle, you can upload a small text or PDF that contains the link. This will remain attached to the invoice and your users can view it. Alternatively, if your business process requires storing URLs, you can create a Custom Business Object with fields such as Invoice Number and URL, you can maintain your links there.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model: Pushing and Pulling data to and from SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Welcome to another series mainly focusing on SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model (UM) and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) integration.

Some time back, I shared how to read and write data to SAC using the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Standard Model (SAP PaPM Cloud SM). Now, as we prepare a new ‚Äúhow-to‚Äù guide focused on the SAP PaPM Cloud UM integration with SAC, it‚Äôs time to set the stage with some key prerequisites.

In this post, I‚Äôll walk you through the high-level steps for consuming data both to and from SAP Analytics Cloud using the SAP PaPM Cloud UM.

Let‚Äôs breakdown the topics into four scenarios:

Inbound means any data going in to SAP PaPM UM from SAC
Scenario 1. SAP PaPM UM pulling data from SAC through SAC Model Connections.

Outbound means any data going out of SAP PaPM UM to SAC
Scenario 2. SAP PAPM UM pushhin Data to SAC through SAC Model Connection

Scenario 3. SAC consuming data from SAP PaPM UM through Odata Connection (Z-Artifacts)

Scenario 4. SAC consuming data from SAP PaPM UM through HANA Live Connection
Note: Auto Generated Calculation Views is not available yet in Universal Model.  There could be a way to do this in BYOD Plan with the use of Business Application Studio where you manually create CV's out of UM's Z Artifacts then share it with SAC.

Prerequisites:

  1. You are subscribed to SAP PaPM Cloud where Universal Model is enabled see Subscription section.
  2. SAC Model available for reading and writing purposes.
  3. You are able to perform Modeling in Universal Model.
  4. You are familiar with How SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) pulls data from SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud)

SCENARIO 1: SAP PAPM UM Consuming Data from SAC through SAC Model Connection

Following the help portal documentation on the inbound integration steps with SAC Model. let‚Äôs proceed:

a. Create BTP Destination. As guidance, refer to the steps we did from previously released blogpost.

Bear in mind that additional properties such as requestHeaders is not mandatory anymore.
In addition, SAC Oauth Client created in SAC Administration > App Integration should have both Data Import (Writing back to SAC) and Data Export (Reading from SAC) Service Access.


b. Prepare an UM Environment containing an explicit field serving as Default Key Field. It can be String or UUID type.

In addition, SAC Model containing sample data sets for data consumption purposes should be available.

c. Create SAC Model Connection. For more info of what each attribute means, see help portal documentation.


d. Once connection is created, go on Edit Mode and add the field to the Model you want to make use of. In this case, I‚Äôd like to only have FactData Model therefore I will unselect the other Models.

e. Choose Sync Model for the FactData to appear in the list of Functions as a Model Entity derived from SAC Model Connection. Create a Reader on top of Model Entity to buffer the data from the source SAC Model. Please note that in the reader function, you need to explicitly add the fields you want to have data of. Else, it will not be populated. 

f. Activate the Environment, Run the Reader and verify data in Model Entity.

Success! Data can now be used for further processing in UM.

SCENARIO 2: SAP PAPM UM Writing Data to SAC through SAC Model Connection

Assuming that you have performed already some processing in UM e.g. Calculations, and you want to write data back to SAC Model. It should be possible by following the steps below:

a. If you need another SAC Model to write onto, you need to reperform SCENARIO 1 to create a Model Entity which will now serve as an output table. I named it differently, created from another connection, to distinguish it as Outbound (OB) FactData.

b. Perform additional processing of Initial FactData as needed. In this case, dummy calculations has been performed e.g. multiply dividend based on some factor.

c. Create a writer function and map the fields.
     Note: You may use other writer types depending on your use case.


d. Once done, Activate the Environment, Run the Writer and verify data in SAC Model.

Data has now been written back to SAC Model.


SCENARIO 3: SAC consuming data from SAP PaPM UM through Odata Connection (Z-Artifacts)


Universal Model API‚Äôs are laid out already in the Business Accelerator Hub which everyone can make use of. In this scenario though, we will make use of Universal Model‚Äôs Z Artifacts using Activity API as starting point serving as a viable alternative option as data source for SAC.   

The steps doesn‚Äôt differ much with how it was written in Odata Connection section of How SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) pulls data from SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud)

Notable adjustments are with:
a. UM relevant Authorities for API Access which is equivalent to the Application Roles. As a hint those with ‚Äú.ace‚Äù are for UM and needs to be added as part of Service Instance Creation. Example JSON is already added which you can make use of. Security-wise, you may decide to include all or only specific roles here signifying what your service key credential user can only do.

b. Universal Model already offers Activity Data URL,  see Data URL , which contains Odata Endpoint of the Model Entity function used within an Activity. This endpoint would contain then the path to which the data are stored as odata.

The above representation is important to know where the root of Data Service URL endpoint for Universal Model comes from.
In the end, your to be Data Service URL would be:

https://<url from your service keys>/ace/ext



Once Odata Connection is setup, Dataset from a datasource can now be checked where you will find the UM‚Äôs Z-Artifact relevant equivalent data.

That's about it. Hope you gained some more knowledge today on the basic integration setup of SAP PaPM UM with SAP Analytics Cloud. Try it out, tweak it and make it your own. Best of luck!

entry.title: SAP AI Agents ‚Äì Revolutionizing How Governments Deliver Value
entry.content:
Nowadays, governments around the world are facing substantial challenges. Budget constraints arising from macroeconomic shocks and geopolitical conditions demand cost efficiency from the government back office (finance, HR, procurement, etc.), while citizens are raising their expectations for highly agile, trustworthy, and effective services.

This is where SAP Business Artificial Intelligence (SAP Business AI) steps in. It encompasses all the latest AI technologies, such as Machine Learning (ML), Generative AI (GenAI), AI Copilots and most recently AI agents, ensuring the public sector can meet these ever-growing demands.

SAP Business AI completely redefines the way governments are operating their business systems ‚Äì it offers one single SAP Joule copilot that serves as an embedded digital assistant. In the daily work of public sector employees, Joule navigates their system landscapes, answers questions, prepares data call outs, and helps execute transactions. It is deeply embedded in the context of government data and works across all departments and applications.

This year, SAP Joule is evolving from a GenAI copilot to being powered by AI agents. It will continue to utilize ML and GenAI skills but at the same time it has advanced its intelligence at an unprecedented scale. Embedded in Joule and the broader SAP Business AI portfolio, AI agents offer a new level of task execution autonomy, helping governments optimize their resources across their IT systems in the most efficient way. Agents don't just perform tasks faster‚Äîthey possess near-human intelligence, allowing them to boost productivity for government services, offer personalization, and provide 24/7 resolution support.

In this blog, we will delve into what SAP Agentic AI means for the public sector and share some concrete use case examples.

Agentic AI for Governments ‚Äì The Edge over GenAI

So, how Agentic AI works? It begins with Large Language Models (LLMs). Trained on the vast amount of data these models are able to provide relevant suggestions to a broad set of questions ‚Äì we call it Generative AI. AI Agents leverage more advanced LLMs called Reasoning Language Models (RLM), that are enhanced with the ability to plan and make judgements. This gives them an opportunity to not only answer questions but solve complex tasks.  When handling a problem, an agent first breaks it down into smaller, more manageable chunks, solves each one, and finally combines the results into a complete and accurate solution.

Unlike a GenAI-powered copilot, which needs a human to tell it what to do before acting, agentic AI can make its own decisions and act proactively. This thinking capability enables four main core abilities: planning, tool usage, collaboration, and reflection.

Let‚Äôs look at these properties by picking up an example of a typical task public sector authorities are regularly dealing with ‚Äì answering citizen queries about their citizenship application status. We will see the extra benefits agents can provide when compared to GenAI assistants.

 

How a Gen-AI Copilot would handle a citizenship process

How an AI Agent would handle a citizenship process

Planning

GenAI Copilot does not plan resolution steps to answer a request; it only follows the instructions received from the user. Its ability to assist would be limited to answering direct questions asked by the applicant who is executing the plan and actions by himself. These questions would be usually limited to understanding passport renewal application process.

The AI Agent plans a series of steps with a concrete plan to independently achieve the given task in the request. It therefore goes beyond just answering questions about the process.

While it is true that before applying citizens are learning about their next steps, when they are waiting for a decision, they typically reach out with specific concerns that they want to resolve ‚Äì for example ‚ÄúMy process is taking longer than the time mentioned in the service description ‚Äì can you address this?‚Äù. Unlike GenAI Copilot, AI Agents can assist in solving these more complex issues.

Tool usage

The GenAI Copilot can access information through tools but cannot execute actions using them. It does not perform tasks in the system; it only provides information based on what it sees. If an applicant is complaining about the process delay, GenAI Copilot would likely be helpful in double checking the process policy and confirming the waiting time has exceeded the regulated one. It can also be helpful in listing the contacts to reach out to. But it won‚Äôt progress further than this.

An agent has a unique ability to reach out to connected tools to carry out the resolution plan. It can choose the tools on its own, use them to consult information, but also to execute actions directly in the system. These tools include databases, software, internet search, a calculator, and more. This helps it to not only advise on the best next actions but execute them.

In our example, by using APIs and database access, an agent can fetch the right application data, create a dispute ticket, describe an issue, assign it to the right human responsible, and send a confirmation to the applicant.

Collaboration

The GenAI Copilot does not consult other collaborators in real time while executing its tasks. It follows the instructions it received and responds to requests based on its own knowledge.

Agents are enjoying teamwork. The AI agents can call for help when they need it. They can ask a human during their task to supervise some of their actions or request clarifications.

They can also ask for a helping hand from other specialized AI agents to carry out specific tasks that require specialized knowledge. By collaborating together, multi-agent systems are even more effective at solving problems.

In our case, this collaboration ability is crucial. Only human processors responsible for a citizenship case can decide on the final resolution decision. So, our agent will involve them in the review of all critical steps made in the resolution process and will ask them to define the final decisions.

When specific rules apply, it will ask a Rule-specialized Agent to provide it with the right guidance and knowledge to tackle its task.

Reflection

The GenAI Copilot mainly produces text output without genuine self-evaluation. It does not review the results it produces. The quality of its output can improve only if the user refines their prompt (prompt engineering) or if the underlying LLMs receive additional training.

The AI Agent will do its best to achieve its goal. As soon as it encounters an obstacle or is at the end of a processus, it will self-evaluate to see if it meets the desired output, then corrects itself, and explores multiple paths until the goal is reached. It learns by itself from his experience to get better next time.

Returning to our citizen process case, it means that in case an agent won‚Äôt be able to find the applicant data in one database, it will check another one. It will learn next time where it can find all the necessary information the quickest.


For public sector agencies the shift from GenAI towards AI agents translates in two major benefits:

  • Higher efficiency and cost reduction: unlike GenAI that automates single content related tasks, agents can take care of complete business processes with more proactiveness and intelligence speeding up large government operations.
  • Higher effectiveness and autonomy: applied in critical areas, advanced agents empower governments to act continuously - even outside of normal hours and will with limited human supervision - extending citizen support and increasing preparedness in disaster and response management.

Those benefits will span across the whole organization‚Äîfrom front office touchpoints to back office departments‚Äî bringing public sector entities to their next level.

Agentic AI Drives Efficiency in the Government Back Office

Like any other organization, a public sector agency needs to be efficient in running its operational processes. Those include procuring goods and services, hiring and training employees, and of course, planning and managing public finances. Back-office tasks involve a lot of repetitive tasks, such as record-keeping, document management, transaction processing, and much more. They often rely on manual workflows that can be time-consuming, error-prone, and non-transparent.

But the biggest challenge the governments are facing in their back-office operations is not being able to scale during periods of unprecedented workload.

Starting from the end of 2024, SAP Joule has been successfully helping governments to leverage GenAI to reduce the operational burden and improve resilience.

Applied right at the center of government finance, S/4HANA Public Sector Management, Joule is already assisting with many content-related tasks such as answering questions about key financial processes in SAP systems, understanding main financial objects and entities and navigating users through SAP applications.

All of it leads to 95% improvement in the speed of learning, search and navigation ‚Äì from 5 minutes usually spent on these tasks to just 30 seconds!


Learn more about Joule for SAP Public Sector Management

Introducing Agentic AI with Joule, let‚Äôs explore how innovation can further drive operational excellence and in the back office. Agents are now able to support tasks of a much higher complexity. In the finance domain, this would mean not only content support and navigation, but the execution of financial transactions themselves. An example of a financial transaction is a budget transfer. Let‚Äôs explore the ways an agent will be able to support.

Let‚Äôs imagine a team manager is considering an extensive overseas business trip. She has a cost estimate but is not sure if she needs special approval from her department director. With the help of document grounding, a budget agent can analyze the travel policy of her agency and confirm her estimate is within the threshold, which means she can go ahead with flight and hotel booking without any extra approvals.

She is then able to reserve some budget. As she is also the cost center responsible for her team, a budget agent is permitting her to look at the available funds. It pulls the overall cost center budget for the year and informs her about the remaining funds. She quickly notices that her business trip estimate is slightly exceeding the travel funds available. She asks the agent to reallocate some funds from the Team Activities budget bucket to the Travel bucket. An SAP agent is then able to confirm the transaction details, create a budget document, and trigger the transfer.


SAP Budget Agent visionary demo screen

SAP agents are operating with the permissions of a user and within the organizational context and can assist with a broader set of tasks than a GenAI Copilot: they are not only communicating in natural language but are also able to perform calculations and work with statistical insights.

Thanks to their extended intelligence and end-to-end support of public finance processes that include many other typically executed tasks like booking commitments or requesting supplements, budget agents will be able to bring an extra efficiency boost of around 30%.

While it is true that SAP public finance agents will be able to take care of many tasks on behalf of government users, humans will always remain in control. To ensure this, each agent is first performing in a draft mode, so that public sector specialists can review the resolution steps and then approve or modify the final decisions.

As noted earlier, agents are particularly effective in managing unprecedented workloads ‚Äî scenarios in which human capacity alone would be insufficient. Let‚Äôs look at one very recent customer example using near Agentic AI technology ‚Äî an advanced, GenAI-powered, context aware automation system‚Äî that demonstrates the potential impact that Agentic AI can have in back-office processes.

The city of Antibes in south of France is not only efficient in its public finance but also is making sure its spending is contributing to making Antibes sustainable and eco-friendly.


Antibes CIO, Patrick Duverger, has led the city to winning multiple innovation awards, including the Territoria Gold Award 2023 by the French Government and SAP Innovation Award 2025

Since the new green law for municipalities came into force, Antibes were looking into ‚Äúgreening‚Äù its budget. This means the city is expected to quantify the environmental impact of their annual budget by tagging expenses to 6 EU Taxonomy objectives and optionally ‚Äì to 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In practice, it means attributing 6,000 budget expenses to one or many green objectives ‚Äì which results in making over 138,000 decisions! Clearly this is beyond a human capacity to manage.

Leveraging Business AI with its advanced natural language processing, SAP was able to help. Based on the descriptions of spend categories and those of the green objectives, AI was able to map all 6,000 budget categories to the relevant sustainable development objective(s) in just about 15-20 minutes!

This allowed the city to ‚Äúgreen‚Äù their finances by providing a view to their inhabitants on how much of Antibes' annual budget was spent on the sustainability goals. Thanks to SAP Business AI, residents of Antibes can clearly see how the city is contributing to a better environment and how public funds are being used ‚Äî fostering greater transparency and trust.


Agentic AI Transforms Citizen Service Delivery

In addition to handling administrative routing tasks in the back office, SAP Agentic AI will also change the way governments serve their constituents. Today citizens expect more straightforward, personalized, and agile services, and it is crucial for public sector agencies to meet these expectations - at a local, regional or federal level, they are eager to change the way they communicate and interact with the service recipients. The overwhelming number of inquiries and human resource constraints is a common challenge to overcome, and here SAP Business AI brings immense value.

A notable example from SAP Business AI impact is the German Federal Foreign Office, which is using SAP's Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) to streamline their services. The Office manages Germany‚Äôs foreign relations with about 230 global missions worldwide. They are dealing with a high volume of inquiries globally and use multiple communication channels. Using SAP BTP powered by natural language processing, as well as GenAI and ML capabilities, they have developed a centralized omnichannel communication processing system that integrates mail, tax, phone, portal and other correspondence modes in one single workflow. Using a ticketing system powered by AI, they were able to automatically classify and assign inquiries to the right processor in their organization. Furthermore, SAP Business AI has been recommending the best resolution to each of the requests, relying on already resolved inquiries.

Since the project‚Äôs launch in 2021 through the completion of its phased rollout in 2023, the German Federal Foreign Office successfully leveraged AI to process more than 2 million messages and over 750,000 inquiries. Today, 50% of all incoming cases are resolved using AI-assisted template responses, eliminating the need for human intervention in those interactions.


For their AI project with SAP, the German Federal Foreign Office received first prize in the ‚ÄúServices Supernova‚Äù category at the 2024 SAP Innovation Awards

As a result, Federal Office employees managed to avoid inconsistent answers to similar questions, assign clear processing and status tracking responsibilities to the teams and, most importantly increase service speed ‚Äì 77% of inquiries are now answered within the same day!

Let's now illustrate how this can translate to Agentic AI and transform citizen service delivery even further ‚Äì based on one of the most complex service examples.

Consider a service officer of a local city council who handles high volumes of complex building permit applications. As legal requirements differ significantly depending on the object that is being built ‚Äì requirements for a house construction are not the same as those for a swimming pool, for instance ‚Äì ensuring regulatory compliance while managing strict service deadlines is challenging. In addition to this, paper-based applications are frequently misplaced and subject to delays, thereby exacerbating the workload of service officers and resulting in applicant dissatisfaction.

A multi-agentic AI workflow from SAP would be ideal to address the situation.  Here‚Äôs how it can work. A builder submits a digital request for a new house construction, an AI-driven automation generates an application case. A multi-agentic AI team, consisting of four specialized agents, is then stepping in.

A document agent ensures application completeness and checks if all required documents are in place and all required information is entered. A permit rules agent extracts decision-making criteria from the legal regulations and knows which criteria an application should fulfill to be granted approval. It then validates the submitted evidence against the requirements and advises the service officer if a positive decision should be granted. A clock agent helps to ensure all processing steps are done within the maximum service delivery time and helps to schedule in-person inspections with the builder. A service agent is there to draft personalized emails to the builder, confirming application entrance, payments, and scheduled inspections.


SAP Application Approval agents visionary demo screen

By leveraging Agentic AI, public sector officers can simplify the processing of complex services, such as building permit applications, expediting turnaround times while enhancing regulatory compliance with more accurate decision-making and applicant satisfaction.

New Horizons in Government Transformation with AI Agents

As we‚Äôve seen, AI agents unlock practical applications and real impact across both front-office and back-office operations. Let us summarize the broader value public sector organizations will be able to seize from Agentic AI.

In the back office, that unites key government operations such as finance, HR, and procurement AI agents are boosting productivity by up to 30%. They act as true teammates and make work more efficient, delivering more with fewer resources and at lower cost:

  • AI agents boost civil servants‚Äô productivity by executing repetitive manual tasks using specialized skills, expertise and knowledge ‚Äì this reduces and prevents errors and allows to process high workloads with better accuracy.
  • They can operate autonomously and across multiple departments, involving humans only at critical decision-making points ‚Äì freeing up their time to focus on making those strategic decisions effectively.
  • Agentic AI helps new government hires to get the hang of complex back-office processes faster and run them with ease.

In the context of citizen services, AI agents provide scalability in times of high demand and enhance citizens satisfaction and trust in government:

  • Agentic AI is redefining the citizen experience by providing 24/7 support to resolve low-risk issues, reduce friction points, and significantly shorten processing times for more complex cases. It also increases personalization by tailoring the content and making decisions based on the most relevant data.
  • AI agents provide vital support during periods of exceptionally high demand. When unemployment rises or other economic shocks occur, and the public sector faces overwhelming volumes of service requests, AI agents help manage workloads beyond human capacity and allow civil servant to stay available in every scenario to answer special demands requiring special attention and compassion that only a human can do.
  • On top of that, civil servants can prioritize citizen transparency, leveraging agents to help with public reporting, and hence increase constituents' trust.

We recognize that despite the power of agentic AI, humans remain accountable for public sector decisions and use of this technology. Accordingly, SAP AI agents are designed under the SAP Global AI Ethics Policy with risk-calibrated autonomy and with great traceability to ensure that humans stay in control to review and approve work performed by agents.

With this considered, AI agents are a true revolution in the Artificial Intelligence space ‚Äì thanks to their advanced intelligence, governments have a new window of opportunity to simplify the way they work and to deliver next level impact in a positive and responsible way to their citizens.

 

 

 

This blog contains SAP visionary material, please check SAP Public Sector roadmap for the upcoming innovations.

entry.title: Optimising Sourcing Cycle Times: Why Your Sourcing Cycle Is Slowing You Down
entry.content:
You‚Äôve seen it before.  An urgent request is raised.  The sourcing process kicks off.  Emails go flying, spreadsheets circulate, stakeholders get looped in, and then‚Ä¶ nothing.  Days turn into weeks.  Meanwhile, business demand backs-up and increases and Procurement are perceived to be a blocker. 

This post kicks off a 3-part series where I‚Äôll break-down a high-impact, low-hype topic: reducing sourcing cycle time. I‚Äôll cover:

  • Why cycle time can drag in modern sourcing processes
  • What to measure (and how)
  • How to reduce sourcing friction using SAP tools, playbooks, and real-world best practices 

Let‚Äôs start with the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù, because speeding up sourcing isn‚Äôt just about efficiency.  It‚Äôs about staying relevant.

Why Sourcing Can Take Time

Let‚Äôs be blunt: sourcing isn‚Äôt slow because of a lack of tools.  It‚Äôs slow because of fragmentation, unclear processes, and too much back-and-forth.  Here‚Äôs what we typically see:

  • Manual input: Requests are vague or incomplete, triggering unnecessary clarification cycles.
  • Policy exceptions: Preferred supplier or contract usage is skipped, often unintentionally.
  • Unstructured negotiations: Offline sourcing processes create chaos, making award decisions painful, and often unfair.
  • Approvals: Sequential and over-engineered approvals stall progress at every turn.

These bottlenecks create a dangerous trade-off: Speed vs. Compliance.  But what if you could have both?

We‚Äôve benchmarked organizations taking 60 to 90 days to go from sourcing request to award, often because they rely on emails, Excel, or disconnected input methods with minimal reuse of assets like templates or libraries. 

Yet SAP benchmarking shows that top quartile performers award in under 30 days, with sourcing cycles that are digitized, governed, and scaled through Guided Sourcing, Full Projects, and automation.

Why This Matters More Than Ever

Speed isn‚Äôt just about being ‚Äòworking‚Äô faster.  It‚Äôs about unlocking the following:

  • Procurement agility to handle shifting supplier landscapes and inflation pressures.
  • Productivity by freeing up FTE hours (often 40-60%) that are now spent manually reviewing events or chasing approvals.
  • Supplier access by engaging broader, more diverse pools earlier and more often.
  • Time-to-savings by accelerating cycle time and expanding spend under management.

From Manual to Governed: Three Procurement Personas

Let‚Äôs talk maturity.  In process mining terms, most sourcing teams fall into one of three archetypes:

 

Manual, Fragmented, Reactive

Semi-Automated but Inconsistent

Streamlined, Proactive, Governed

Events triggered via emails or Excel. No template reuse.  Sequential approvals.

Some Ariba use, but lacking standardization or template enforcement.  Partial use of Full Projects.

Intake via Guided Sourcing forms, event libraries, milestone-driven workflows, AI recommendations.

90+ days to award, poor traceability, delays in onboarding.

Some cycle time improvements, but wide variance.

Under 30 days to award. High user engagement. Embedded best practices.

 

What It‚Äôs Costing You (and Your Business)

 

KPI

Why It Matters

Top 25% Benchmark

Avg. Sourcing Cycle Time

Core metric for time-to-value

11 days

% of Events Awarded in Ariba

Shows platform adoption

67.27%

% of RFP Events Awarded

Indicates strong evaluation structure

67.26%

Sourcing Events per Project Owner

Measures team productivity

15.29 events

Supplier-Event Pairs per Event

Reflects sourcing breadth

3.57

Sourcing Savings Rate

Captures business value of speed

13.65%

So Why Wait?

If you‚Äôre still launching events manually or waiting 3-4 weeks for sourcing approvals, it‚Äôs time to rethink.

You don‚Äôt need a transformation project to get started.  You need a sourcing speed audit, a few smart quick wins (e.g., template reuse, Guided Sourcing adoption), and a structured enablement plan tied to KPIs.

That‚Äôs what Part 2 of this blog series will unpack: ‚ÄúWhat to Do‚Äù, a breakdown of where cycle time delays occur and which SAP features eliminate them.

entry.title: Re: Scheduling a story based on a live SAP Datasphere sol...
entry.content:
Hello Joscha,

The new functionality is very recent. You might find more information in the Influence comments.

Scheduling a Publication on SAP Datasphere data 

Just to let you know, the connection that needs to be created is in the SAC tenant with the field connection type = Tunnel. The SAP support team mentioned that in upcoming updates they will allow modifying already created connections (those created with connection type = Direct). Furthermore, you also need to create a formation in SAP BTP.  Official documentation:

Configure Scheduling of Publication

Regards,

Miquel

entry.title: Re: How to clone a CAP based solution from one HANA Cloud...
entry.content:
If you use HDI containers as persistence for your CAP application, you can export the complete container from PRD HANA to cloud storage and import it to the TEST HANA:
Export an SAP HDI Container for Copy Purposes to a Cloud Store 
Import an SAP HDI Container for Copy Purposes from a Cloud Store 
Importing and Exporting Data (chose your preferred cloud storage provider)
During import you can rename the source container name to your target container name. 
You can either export/import to/from your own cloud storage (like an S3 bucket) or you can use the BTP Object Store service. 
There is also a nice blog on this topic: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blogs-by-sap/export-import-an-sap-hdi-container-for-copy-pur...
As the blog was published two years ago, some details may have changed (for instance there is typically no need anymore to import cloud storage certificates, as these are already provided with latest SAP HANA Cloud releases). So always double check the current product documenation. 
Regards, 
  Alex
